subject: Re: [junit] Instantiated TestCase won't run tests
msgSnippet: ... E-mail can cause a lot of misunderstandings, especially when one projects their own assumptions into what they are reading. ... That is understandable.
messageBody:
> But can you understand why what you wrote could have come across that
> way? It was pretty clear to me.

E-mail can cause a lot of misunderstandings, especially when one projects their
own assumptions into what they are reading.

> OK. Did you get the explanation you wanted? Sometimes the explanation
> takes pages and pages, and I don't have the energy to write that out
> every time someone asks.

That is understandable. But if you could point me to these pages then I would
voraciously consume them. I have of course read all the attached documentation
that comes with JUnit, and I have been trying to make use of the JUnit-Addons
package.

> I apologize for my tone. I was tired, and it seemed like you were asking
> for our advice, then disregarding it anyway. You can understand how that
> might be enervating.

Sure, but it is also enervating when you are told to give it up when you know
that there is more to the story.

I believe that I have found my own answer. At least here are my thoughts at the
moment. Data driven testing in the way that I am trying to do it is not easily
supported in JUnit. There is likely a reason for this, since a lot of thought
has gone into producing JUnit. I now believe that my approach is not in keeping
with JUnit. Since I am running the actual metadata from the application through
the test, I am doing more of a data driven functional type of testing. A
solution that appears more consistent with JUnit and unit testing in general
seems to be to make some mock metadata classes that are specially designed to
exercise my code in the test. This way my test is not dependent on any
production code rather than the actual class that it is testing, and I am not
trying to dynamically find all the production code and iterate through it all.
Instead I am looking to carefully engineer my own metadata to exercise my tests.
To implement this I basically wrote an abstract test class, and then made
specific subclasses that are each mainly concerned with building specific mock
data. It is okay that this data is hardcoded rather than dynamic because I am
looking to exercise the code by carefully building my own data rather than
running through all data that currently exists in the application. I was
basically being lazy by using data that already existed and not crafting my own.
But running actual production data does seem useful at least a few times when
testing your own tests, just because there is some potential in catering to your
own tests when writing your own data as well. Does that part make sense? This
is the only thing that feels strange about my current ideas. Am I on the right
track?

I know that there are many frustrations with dealing with a mailing list. I
applaud your taking the time to answer peopleÂ’s questions, and feel very lucky
to have the opportunity to carry on a dialog with an expert. Thanks so much for
your time getting me past this hurdle.
